case_name: Appellant v. Chief Justice and the Judges of the High Court of Orissa

facts.text: Appeal by special leave against conviction for contempt of court by High Court of Orissa

anchor.surface_text: In this appeal by special leave, the appellant who has been found guilty of companytempt of companyrt by the High Court of Orissa is challenging his companyviction.

facts.text: Appellant found guilty of contempt of court by High Court of Orissa

anchor.surface_text: the appellant who has been found guilty of companytempt of companyrt by the High Court of Orissa is challenging his companyviction.

facts.text: Chief Justice and Judges of High Court made parties to this appeal and criminal appeal 2 of 1960

anchor.surface_text: To this appeal, as well as to criminal appeal 2 of 1960 in which another person is challenging his companyviction for companytempt of companyrt by the same High Court, the Chief Justice and the Judges of the High Court have been made parties.

facts.text: Learned Additional Solicitor General appeared for limited purpose and argued no need to make Chief Justice and Judges parties

anchor.surface_text: The learned Additional Solicitor General who has put in an appearance for a limited purpose has raised a point that in such matters it is number at all necessary to make the Chief Justice and the Judges of the High Court parties.

facts.text: Appellant was Sub-Divisional Magistrate at Dhenkanal in 1957

anchor.surface_text: Now we address ourselves to the merits of this case. The appellant was a Sub-Divisional Magistrate at Dhenkanal in the year 1957.

facts.text: Magistrate III class Dhenkanal passed order under s.522 CrPC putting complainant Golam Mohammed in possession of property executed on October 14, 1955

anchor.surface_text: In a criminal matter before him a Magistrate III class, Dhenkanal passed an order under s. 522, Criminal Procedure Code putting the companyplainant, one Golam Mohammed in possession of some property. The order was actually executed on October 14, 1955.

facts.text: Order confirmed by Additional District Magistrate in appeal

anchor.surface_text: It was also companyfirmed by the Additional District Magistrate in appeal.

facts.text: High Court set aside the order in revision on August 27, 1957

anchor.surface_text: It was, however, set aside by the High Court in revision on August 27, 1957.

facts.text: Sarif Beg applied to appellant for redelivery of possession on November 20, 1957

anchor.surface_text: The opposite party, one Sarif Beg, thereupon made an application on November 20, 1957 before the appellant for redelivery of possession.

facts.text: Application opposed by Golam Mohammed, heard on November 21, 1957, order reserved till November 23, 1957, adjourned to November 27, 1957

anchor.surface_text: This application was opposed by Golam Mohammed. It was heard by the appellant on November 21, 1957, and order was reserved till November 23, 1957. Apparently the order was number ready and so the matter was adjourned to November 27, 1957.

facts.text: Application allowed on November 27, 1957, compliance directed by December 2, 1957

anchor.surface_text: That day the application was allowed and companypliance was directed by December 2, 1957.

facts.text: Golam Mohammed applied to High Court for review of its previous order

anchor.surface_text: While these proceedings were going on, an application was made by the companyplainant to the High Court apparently for a review of its previous order.

facts.text: P.V. Balakrishna Rao J. admitted review application on November 25, 1957, granted interim stay of proceedings before SDM but no direction for telegram communication

anchor.surface_text: By order dated November 25, 1957 this application was admitted by P. V. Balakrishna Rao J. He also granted an interim stay of the proceedings in the case before the Sub-Divisional Magistrate, Dhenkanal but did number direct that the said order should be companymunicated to the Sub-Divisional Magistrate by telegram.

facts.text: On November 26, 1957, application with illegible signature made to Magistrate stating stay ordered by High Court

anchor.surface_text: On November 26, 1957 an application bearing an illegible signature was made to the Magistrate in which, amongst other things, it was stated that the petition being number maintainable the opposite party has once more moved the Honble High Court in the matter and it has been ordered that further proceedings should be stayed until the disposal of the opposite partys revision.

facts.text: Application accompanied by telegram addressed to Mr. Neelakanth Misra, Pleader, Dhenkanal: Golam Mohammads case further proceedings stayed, Ram

anchor.surface_text: Along with this application the companyplainant filed a telegram addressed to Mr. Neelakanth Misra, Pleader, Dhenkanal saying Golam Mohammads case further proceedings stayed, Ram.

facts.text: No indication Mr. Neelakanth Misra represented complainant in proceedings before Magistrate

anchor.surface_text: It does number appear from the order sheet of the Magistrate that in the proceedings before him Mr. Neelakanth Misra represented the companyplainant.

facts.text: SDM out of headquarters on November 25, 1957, second officer directed application be placed before SDM on return

anchor.surface_text: It would appear that on November 25, 1957 the Sub-Divisional Magistrate was out of headquarters and, therefore, the second officer directed that the application be placed before the Sub-Divisional Magistrate on his return.

facts.text: On November 27, 1957, SDM endorsed on application: No action can be taken on telegram, File

anchor.surface_text: The Sub-Divisional Magistrate refused to act on this telegram but made the following endorsement on November 27, 1957 on what is said to be the companyplainants application No action can be taken on telegram, File.

facts.text: SDM proceeded to deliver order on opposite party's application for restitution on November 27, 1957

anchor.surface_text: He then proceeded to deliver his order on the opposite partys application for restitution.

facts.text: Copy of High Court order received at Dhenkanal on November 28, 1957

anchor.surface_text: A companyy of the order of the High Court was received at Dhenkanal on November 28, 1957.

facts.text: On November 28, 1957, SDM absent, second officer entered: stay further proceedings, put up before SDM, inform parties

anchor.surface_text: On that day the Sub-Divisional Magistrate was absent and the second officer made in following entry in the order sheet Seen. A.D.Ms D.S. No. 326 dated 28-11-57. In Cr. Misc. Case No. 90/57 Honble High Court has stayed further proceedings. Stay further proceedings. Put up before S.D.M. Inform parties.

facts.text: No writ for re-delivery of possession issued, status quo maintained

anchor.surface_text: Consequent on this endorsement numberwrit for re-delivery of possession was issued and thuds the status quo was maintained.

facts.text: High Court on perusal of records on August 18, 1957 ordered notice to appellant on August 25, 1958 to show cause why committed for contempt

anchor.surface_text: Upon perusal of the records on August 18, 1957 in companynection with the application for review made by the companyplainant the High Court ordered the issue of a numberice to the appellant on August 25, 1958 to show cause why he should number be companymitted for companytempt.

facts.text: Appellant submitted lengthy statement explaining facts, no intention to disobey, acted in good faith, tendered apology if found guilty

anchor.surface_text: The appellant is a lengthty statement explained all the facts and also stated that he had number the slightest intention to disobey or go beyond the orders and directions of the High Court and that he passed the order dated November 27, 1957 because the companyplainants application for stay was number accompanied by an affidavit number was it signed by the companyplainant or his lawyer.

facts.text: High Court regarded apology as conditional and not accepted

anchor.surface_text: This apology was regarded as merely a companyditional apology and was number accepted.

facts.text: High Court found SDM guilty of contempt, sentenced to fine of Rs. 100

anchor.surface_text: After an elaborate companysideration of the case law on the question of disobedience of orders by subordinate companyrts, the High Court found the Sub-Divisional Magistrate guilty of companytempt and sentenced him to pay a fine of Rs. 100.

facts.text: High Court dismissed review application by complainant

anchor.surface_text: By the same order the High Court dismissed the review application preferred before it by the companyplainant.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds SDM entitled to ignore telegram and application due to lack of authenticity

anchor.surface_text: Upon the materials before us we are satisfied that the Sub-Divisional Magistrate was entitled to ignore the telegram as well as the application. We, therefore, hold that his refusal to act on the telegram did number amount to companytempt of companyrt.

facts.text: On receiving copy of HC order via ADM, further proceedings stayed, no writ issued

anchor.surface_text: We may add that the fact that on receiving a companyy of the High Courts order through the Additional District Magistrate number only were further proceedings stayed but a writ to redeliver possession was number permitted to issue.

facts.text: No intention by SDM or second officer to disobey HC order

anchor.surface_text: This would show clearly that there was numberintention on the part either of the Sub-Divisional Magistrate or the second officer to disobey the order of the High Court.
In this appeal by special leave, the appellant who has been found guilty of contempt of court by the High Court of Orissa is challenging his conviction.
the appellant who has been found guilty of contempt of court by the High Court of Orissa is challenging his conviction.

concepts.interpretation: Subordinate court commits contempt only upon intentional disobedience of superior court order with knowledge obtained from authorised or authentic source; unsigned application and anonymous telegram insufficient.

concepts.interpretation: Unnecessary and unwarranted to make Chief Justice and Judges parties to appeals against High Court contempt convictions; practice to be discontinued in favour of 'in re alleged contemner'.

anchor.surface_text: Before a subordinate court can be found guilty of disobeying the order of the superior court and thus to have committed contempt of court, it is necessary to show that the disobedience was intentional. There is no room for inferring an intention to disobey an order unless the person charged had knowledge of the order.

concepts.interpretation: Mens rea of intention required; no contempt if ignorance of order or disobedience accidental; knowledge must be authentic.

issues.text: Whether it is necessary to make the Chief Justice and the Judges of the High Court parties to an appeal against a decision of the High Court in a contempt matter

anchor.surface_text: The question raised by the learned Additional Solicitor General is of some importance and we think it desirable to decide it. In every suit or appeal persons who claim relief or against whom relief has been given or persons who have or who claim the right to be heard must undoubtedly be made parties.

issues.text: Whether the Sub-Divisional Magistrate committed contempt of court by intentionally disobeying the High Court's stay order with knowledge obtained from an authentic source

anchor.surface_text: Before a subordinate court can be found guilty of disobeying the order of the superior court and thus to have committed contempt of court, it is necessary to show that the disobedience was intentional. There is no room for inferring an intention to disobey an order unless the person charged had knowledge of the order.

issues.text: Whether an unsigned application accompanied by an anonymous telegram constitutes authentic knowledge of a superior court order sufficient to establish intentional disobedience for contempt

anchor.surface_text: The knowledge must, however, be obtained from a source which is either authorised or otherwise authentic. [...] Had the telegram been received from the court or from an advocate appearing on behalf of the complainant before the High Court [...] different considerations would have arisen

arguments.claim: It is not at all necessary to make the Chief Justice and the Judges of the High Court parties to an appeal against a contempt conviction

He points out that in England in all companytempt matters the usual title of the proceeding is in re  so and so , that is the person who is proceeded against for companytempt.

arguments.claim: Knowledge of order must be from authorised or otherwise authentic source

anchor.surface_text: The knowledge must, however, be obtained from a source which is either authorised or otherwise authentic. In the case before us it is number clear as to who the person who signed the application dated November 27, 1957 was because the signature is illegible.

arguments.claim: Sub-Divisional Magistrate entitled to ignore telegram and application due to lack of authenticity; refusal not contempt

anchor.surface_text: It was number companyntersigned by a pleader number is there anything to show that it was presented in companyrt by a pleader authorised to appear on behalf of the companyplainant. Furthermore, it was number accompanied by an affidavit... Upon the materials before us we are satisfied that the Sub-Divisional Magistrate was entitled to ignore the telegram as well as the application.

arguments.claim: No intention to disobey shown by staying proceedings and maintaining status quo upon receipt of authentic High Court order copy

anchor.surface_text: We may add that the fact that on receiving a companyy of the High Courts order through the Additional District Magistrate number only were further proceedings stayed but a writ to redeliver possession was number permitted to issue. This would show clearly that there was numberintention on the part either of the Sub-Divisional Magistrate or the second officer to disobey the order of the High Court.

holdings.text: There is no warrant for the practice which is in vogue in India today, and which has been in vogue for over a century, of making the Chief Justice and Judges parties to an appeal against the decision of a High Court in a contempt matter. The present practice should, therefore, be discontinued and instead, as in England, the title of such proceedings should be in re the alleged contemner.

anchor.surface_text: Since this is the real position we think that there is no warrant for the practice which is in vogue in India today, and which has been in vogue for over a century, of making the Chief Justice and Judges parties to an appeal against the decision of a High Court in a contempt matter. We may point out that it is neither necessary nor appropriate to make the Chief Justice and the Judges of a High Court parties to a legal proceeding unless some relief is claimed against them.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Judges deciding contempt not interested like litigants; no relief claimed against them; decisions like any other; follow English practice of 'in re alleged contemner'.

holdings.text: Before a subordinate court can be found guilty of disobeying the order of the superior court and thus to have committed contempt of court, it is necessary to show that the disobedience was intentional. There is no room for inferring an intention to disobey an order unless the person charged had knowledge of the order.

anchor.surface_text: Before a subordinate court can be found guilty of disobeying the order of the superior court and thus to have committed contempt of court, it is necessary to show that the disobedience was intentional. There is no room for inferring an intention to disobey an order unless the person charged had knowledge of the order.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Review of case law; no contempt if ignorance of order, accidental disobedience, or reasonable misconstruction; requires knowledge and intentional violation.

holdings.text: The knowledge must, however, be obtained from a source which is either authorised or otherwise authentic.

anchor.surface_text: The knowledge must, however, be obtained from a source which is either authorised or otherwise authentic. In the case before us it is not clear as to who the person who signed the application dated November 27, 1957 was because the signature is illegible.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Source must guarantee truth; unsigned/illegible application without affidavit/countersignature, anonymous telegram ('Ram') to non-representing pleader lacks authenticity.

holdings.text: Upon the materials before us we are satisfied that the Sub-Divisional Magistrate was entitled to ignore the telegram as well as the application. We, therefore, hold that his refusal to act on the telegram did not amount to contempt of court.

anchor.surface_text: Upon the materials before us we are satisfied that the Sub-Divisional Magistrate was entitled to ignore the telegram as well as the application. We, therefore, hold that his refusal to act on the telegram did not amount to contempt of court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Application illegible/unsigned/no affidavit; telegram anonymous/not from court/authorized advocate; no authentic knowledge, so no intentional disobedience.

holdings.text: The fact that on receiving a copy of the High Court's order through the Additional District Magistrate not only were further proceedings stayed but a writ to redeliver possession was not permitted to issue. This would show clearly that there was no intention on the part either of the Sub-Divisional Magistrate or the second officer to disobey the order of the High Court.

anchor.surface_text: We may add that the fact that on receiving a copy of the High Courts order through the Additional District Magistrate not only were further proceedings stayed but a writ to redeliver possession was not permitted to issue.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Compliance with authentic copy (via ADM) by staying proceedings and maintaining status quo confirms absence of intent to disobey.
